title: Lee Child-Killing Floor
description:
Welcome to Margrave, GeorgiaÃ¢â‚¬â€but donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get too attached to the townsfolk, who are either in on a giant conspiracy, or hurtling toward violent deaths, or both.

ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not much of a welcome for Jack Reacher, a casualty of the ArmyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s peace dividend whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s drifted into town idly looking for traces of a long dead black jazzman. Not only do the local cops arrest him for murder, but the chief of police turns eyewitness to place him on the scene, even though Reacher was getting on a bus in Tampa at the time. Two surprises follow: The murdered man wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t the only victim, and he was ReacherÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s brother whom he hadnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t seen in seven years. So Reacher, who so far hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t had anything personal against the crooks who set him up for a weekend in the state pen at Warburton, clicks into overdrive.

Banking on the help of the only two people in Margrave he can trustÃ¢â‚¬â€a Harvard-educated chief of detectives who hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t been on the job long enough to be on the take, and a smart, scrappy officer whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s taken him to her bedÃ¢â‚¬â€ he sets out methodically in his brotherÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s footsteps, trying to figure out why his cellmate in Warburton, a panicky banker whose cell-phone number turned up in JoeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s shoe, confessed to a murder he obviously didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t commit; trying to figure out why all the out-of-towners on JoeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s list of recent contacts were as dead as he was; and trying to stop the local carnage or at least direct it in more positive ways. Though the testosterone flows as freely as printerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s ink, Reacher is an unobtrusively sharp detective in his quieter momentsÃ¢â‚¬â€not that there are many of them to judge by.
